title: Ekko? More like Red-ko!
body:
Cmon, don't tell me I was the only one. 

In honor of the new champ and Jen Zee, the amazing artist behind Supergiants' games, but specifically Transistor, here's Ekko in Red's pose.

I take no credit for the pose, definitely Jen Zee's doing, but I did draw this taking inspiration identical to the picture posted below. Tried to mimic her legendary style, but to little avail.

http://i.imgur.com/NoqLBpx.jpg

reference + inspiration:
http://imgur.com/cACUtGW.jpg

UPDATE: did a background that I'm pretty satisfied with. Again, I try not to spend hours on fan art because it's not a valid portfolio piece (in my head).

plug time: 
tripplejaz.deviantart.com
facebook.com/tripplejaz.

I thought about doing the memorial, but there's not enough space in the room (given the visual context of the reveal video) without it feeling out of place/claustrophobic as the viewer. So I went with a different view from the same room, including the horrendous zaunite.
A Transistor styled game with Ekko would be quite something.

It's called Bastion.

http://vignette4.wikia.nocookie.net/bastion/images/3/3c/The_Kid.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20110729210206

Aside of both being post-apocalyptic dystopias, they're completely different games.

Transistor-styled would actually be much more fitting for Ekko due to the Turn() mechanic.

Cloudbank isn't what I would call a dystopia, at least not a traditional one. I would not call them completely different games either; Bastion and Transistor do have some similarities, which is a given, as both were made by the same group. Aesthetics is the greatest distinction between them though. I was only citing Bastion for

Cloudbank is definitely a dystopia, given that it's a self-proclaimed democratic utopia that houses a perpetually unhappy society whose minority and creative minds are consistently choked down by the voting system. A broken utopia that hurts its own people is the very definition of a dystopia.

Caelondia, on the other hand, is a communist dystopia. Yes, Rucks paints it as a wonderful place, but keep in mind that Rucks also created the superweapon that shattered the world and killed an entire continent worth of people. He's not the finest judge of anything.

As for gameplay, yeah, they're both played from top-down. Bastion is best compared to Zelda in terms of gameplay flow though, while Transistor is basically Devil May Cry where you execute combos by pausing the game into a tactical overlay and inputting commands instead of mashing button combinations. I feel the latter would be more fitting for Ekko because Red's entire thing is that she uses Turn() to speed up her own time and fast-forwards herself through the motions while the world largely cannot keep up.

Admittance: I own physical collector's editions of both games. I *may* be moderately obsessed with Supergiants' work. >_>

I cannot fault you for taking such a heavy interest in them, as both games are very good at delivering an enjoyable gameplay experience and fascinating setting to explore, not to mention a rather poignant narrative. I haven't played either, though dearly wish to, as my current funds are uncomfortably tight. However, I have watched walkthroughs from beginning to end, adore Transistor's setting - I love Art Deco - and the soundtracks are some of the most interesting piece I have ever heard.

I agree Ekko's time-based thematic would be more suitable to the tactical engagements of Transistor, in addition to the science fiction elements that borders on magic. Though with the nature of Cloudbank, magic could be more appropriately called programming and executing functions. Not to mention both Red and Ekko have a large, dull-edged blade with a cyan coloration.

Bastion fits in with Ekko's overall aesthetic, that being a dark-skinned character with light hair in a scavenged get-up. Really, that is the only reason I suggested Bastion over Transistor, though Transistor fits more closely from a gameplay perspective.

Also, Tesla Effect said style, not an exact replica, so I took some liberties with his comment.
